Content-Type: text/plain;

Another method might be to use basic images to test the algorithm,
for example if your algoirithm converts from a trianglar image to a
hexagonal one (im making this up as i go along) can you provide a set of
before/after images, os say a triangle being converted to a hexagon, that
that prove the algorithm is doing what it should do for those cases?

-----Original Message-----
From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbr@...]
Sent: 10 January 2002 00:08
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit]


Can you reduce the mapping to something purely numeric that you can test?
That would be easier to express in a (programming language-based) test case.
Then you should pick a few (a very small number, if possible) test images to
eye-ball now and then to double check that nothing's gone wrong.
 
Remember: you just need to test the mapping somehow; it doesn't have to use
the images as input/output.

*********** REPLY SEPARATOR ***********

On 1/9/2002 at 9:39 AM David V. Olivier wrote:

I use JUnit for about 90% of my code.  I would like to use it for 100% but 
I consistently find automated testing of certain types of functionality 
particular difficult to accomplish.  My work is in digital mapping, and I 
find complex operations on large data sets problematic.

Let me give a specific example:

I am currently implementing functionality to warp satellite images from one 
mapping projection to another.  The image is distorted according to a 
complex formula.  On a low level, I can test that for a given input my 
implementation of the formula provides the result I expect, but on a higher 
level I haven't been able to automate verification of that the final image 
is correct.  I have only been able to superimpose the result on a 
background map I know is correct and eyeball the results.

I would be curious to hear feedback from more experienced JUnit users on 
approaches to testing this type necessarily complex behavior.   I know that 
Mock Objects are used to simplify the testing of certain types of otherwise 
problematic scenarios, but I have no first hand experience with them and 
don't clearly see their applicability in a case like this.  Have others 
found that there are certain areas where, in practice, they simply don't 
apply JUnit as the ratio of effort to develop the test compared to benefit 
gained by the test is too high (certainly the issue of testing GUIs has 
received plenty of attention on this list)?

I dislike leaving gaps in my tests, particularly in coverage for the most 
difficult functionality, as these are the areas most likely to contain bugs.


David Olivier
Naval Research Laboratory
Digital Mapping, Charting & Geodesy Analysis Program
Code 7440.2



J. B. Rainsberger,
President, Diaspar Software Services
